Expected Values¶

Review: probability density functions provide a global overview of the random variable's behavior.

In [88]:
suppressWarnings(library('gridExtra'))
suppressWarnings(library('ggplot2'))
In [8]:
discrete <- ggplot(data.frame(x = 1:20, y = dbinom(1:20, 20, 0.8)), aes(x = x, y = y)) + 
            geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
            scale_y_continuous(expand = c(0.01, 0)) + xlab("Random Variable X") + ylab("Density") + 
            theme(plot.title = element_text(size = rel(1.2), vjust = 1.5))

continous<-ggplot(data.frame(x = c(-4, 4)), aes(x = x)) + 
           stat_function(fun = dnorm, args = list(0, 1),colour = "dodgerblue3",size = 0.7) +
           scale_x_continuous(name = "Random Variable Y") + 
           scale_y_continuous(name = "Density") +
           theme_bw()

options(repr.plot.width=7, repr.plot.height=3)
grid.arrange(discrete, continous, ncol=2)
  • **Advantage**: PDF details the likelihood of observing each value in the entire domain of the random variable.
  • **Disadvantage**: it may provide more information than necessary. Often it is more helpful to summarize certain features of the distribution in only one number.

Central tendency: intuitively, a central tendency measure is a value where the random variable realizations will tend to lie. One of the most widely used central tendency measures is the expected value.

Definition 1 (expected value): let XX be a discrete random variable with probability function PX(k)PX(k). The expected value of XX is denoted by E(X)E(X) and is given by

E(X)=∑all kk⋅pX(k)E(X)=∑all kk⋅pX(k)

Similarly, if YY is a continuous random variable with pdf fY(y)dyfY(y)dy

E(Y)=∫∞−∞y⋅fY(y)dyE(Y)=∫−∞∞y⋅fY(y)dy

Example 1:¶

Calculating the expected value of the binomial distribution from scratch. In class you covered Theorem 3.5.1 from the textbook. The theorem states that if XX is a binomial random variable with parameters nn and pp, them E(X)=npE(X)=np.

In [77]:
# Let's consider the binomial random variable with parameters n=20 and p=0.8

n <-20
p <-0.8
print(paste0('E(X)=',n*p))

[1] "E(X)=16"

To better understand how to apply the definition of expected value and to practice some R skills, let's calculate the expectation of the binomial from scratch:

  • First, we need to know what is the domain of the random variable XX. That is, the set of kk values for which pX(k)>0pX(k)>0. Clearly, it is impossible to obtain more successes than the total number of trials while obtaining zero successes is still plausible.
In [16]:
# One easy way to confirm the previous statment is to use:
dbinom(0:21, n, p)

Following the expected value formula (E(X)=∑all kk⋅pX(k))(E(X)=∑all kk⋅pX(k)), we need to take all the values of k∈[0,20]k∈[0,20] and multiply each by its likelihood of occurrence. Let's illustrate the process with a graph:

In [27]:
ggplot(data=data.frame(k=0:20,density=dbinom(0:20, n, p)),aes(x = k, y = density)) +
  geom_col() +
  geom_text(aes(label = round(density,2), y = density + 0.01), position = position_dodge(0.9),size = 3,vjust = 0)

E(X)=∑all kk⋅pX(k)=0.0004×10+0.007×11+0.022×12+⋯+0.011×20E(X)=∑all kk⋅pX(k)=0.0004×10+0.007×11+0.022×12+⋯+0.011×20

In [75]:
# Create a function to calculate the expectation of a discrete random variable

Ed <- function(pdf, pdf_parameters, ki = -Inf, kf = Inf){
    expectation <- 0
    for (j in ki:kf){
        expectation <- expectation + do.call(pdf,c(j,pdf_parameters))*j
    }
    return(expectation)
}
In [78]:
Ed(dbinom,list(n,p),0,20)
16

To confirm that the function works for any arbitrary discrete function. I will also try the Hypergeometric Distribution. In class you showed that if XX distributes hypergeometric with parameters r,wr,w and nn, then E(X)=rnr+wE(X)=rnr+w. In words, rr and ww represent the number of red and white balls. A sample of size nn is drawn from the container.

In [79]:
# Let's assume n=20, r=5, w=15. 
n <- 11
r <- 10 
w <- 15
print(paste0('E(X)=',((r*n)/(r+w))))

[1] "E(X)=4.4"
In [80]:
Ed(dhyper,list(r,w,n),0,11)
4.4

Example 2:¶

Extension to any continuous variable

The normal distribution has two parameters: mean (μμ) and variance (σ2σ2). If XX is a random variable following a normal distribution with parameters μμ and σ2σ2 (X∼N(μ,σ2))(X∼N(μ,σ2)), it can be shown that E(X)=μE(X)=μ.

Using the normal distribution as the base, this code calculates the expected value using Definition 1:

In [83]:
integrate(function(x){x * dnorm(x,mean=3)}, -Inf, Inf)

3 with absolute error < 0.00033

Now let's construct a function to calculate the expected value of any arbitrary continuous variable. Instead of using the do.call approach, this function uses the three dots constructions to allow for arbitrary parameters:

In [85]:
Ec <- function(pdf, ..., ki = -Inf, kf = Inf) {
  integrate(function(x){x * pdf(x, ...)}, ki, kf)
}
In [86]:
Ec(dnorm, mean=3)

3 with absolute error < 0.00033

To check that the function works for any arbitrary continuous random variable. Let's take the example of an exponential distribution. This distribution predicts the amount of waiting time until the next event. For example the amount of time you need to wait until the bus arrives (arrival time). The exponential distribution takes the parameter λλ as input. Intuitively, this parameter represents the proportion of times that the event occurs during a unit of time.

  • Assuming Y∼exp(λ)Y∼exp(λ), it can be shown that E(Y)=1/λE(Y)=1/λ
In [115]:
exp <- ggplot(data.frame(x = c(0, 6)), aes(x=x)) +
       stat_function(fun = dexp, args = list(0.5), aes(colour = "Lambda=0.5"),size = 0.7) +
       stat_function(fun = dexp, args = list(1.5), aes(colour = "Lambda=1.5"),size = 0.7) +
       scale_colour_manual("Parameter Values", values = c("red", "dodgerblue3")) +
       xlab("Exponential Random Variable Y") + ylab("Density")


options(repr.plot.width=6, repr.plot.height=4)
exp
In [123]:
Ec(dexp, rate=0.5)
Ec(dexp, rate=1.5)

2 with absolute error < 7.7e-06
0.6666667 with absolute error < 8.1e-05
In [122]:
exp_ev <- ggplot(data.frame(x = c(0, 6)), aes(x=x)) +
          stat_function(fun = dexp, args = list(0.5), aes(colour = "Lambda=0.5"),size = 0.7) +
          stat_function(fun = dexp, args = list(1.5), aes(colour = "Lambda=1.5"),size = 0.7) +
          geom_vline(xintercept = Ec(dexp, rate=0.5)$value, color="red", linetype="dotted") +
          geom_vline(xintercept = Ec(dexp, rate=1.5)$value, color="dodgerblue3", linetype="dotted") +
          scale_colour_manual("Parameter Values", values = c("red", "dodgerblue3")) +
          xlab("Exponential Random Variable Y") + ylab("Density")

options(repr.plot.width=6, repr.plot.height=4)
exp_ev

The Expected Value of a Function of a Random Variable¶

Sometimes the object of interest is not the random variable XX itself but transformations of it. Sometimes the distribution of the new random variable Y=g(X)Y=g(X) is easy to compute and Definition 1 can be used to calculate the expectation of YY. In cases when the calculation of the pdf of YY is complicated, the following theorem can be used:

Theorem 1: Suppose XX is a discrete random variable with pdf pX(k)pX(k). Let g(X)g(X) be a function of XX. Then the expected value of the random variable g(X)g(X) is given by

E[g(X)]=∑all kg(k)⋅pX(k),E[g(X)]=∑all kg(k)⋅pX(k),

provided that ∑a∥,k|g(k)|pX(k)<∞∑a‖,k|g(k)|pX(k)<∞.

If YY is a continuous random variable with pdf fY(y)fY(y), and if g(Y)g(Y) is a continuous function, then the expected value of the random variable g(Y)g(Y) is

E[g(Y)]=∫∞−∞g(y)⋅fY(y)dyE[g(Y)]=∫−∞∞g(y)⋅fY(y)dy

provided that ∫∞−∞|g(y)|fY(y)dy<∞∫−∞∞|g(y)|fY(y)dy<∞.

Example 3:¶

Expected value of a Chi-squared distribution (χ2χ2-distribution).

It can be shown by methods discussed in chapter 3.8 (Transforming and Combining Random Variables) that if Z1,…,ZkZ1,…,Zk are independent, standard normal random variables, then

Q=∑i=1kZ2iQ=∑i=1kZi2

distributes Chi-squared with kk degrees of freedom (Q∼χ2(k))(Q∼χ2(k)). Thus, if k=1k=1, Q=Z2∼χ2(1)Q=Z2∼χ2(1). It is also possible to show that E(χ2(k))=kE(χ2(k))=k so that when k=1k=1, E(Q)=1E(Q)=1.

If we use the function we already created and pass as inputs the Chi-squared distribution with 1 degree of freedom we should get the result that the expectation equals one.

In [124]:
Ec(dchisq, df=1)

1 with absolute error < 4.9e-05

For pedagogical purposes, let's use Theorem 1 to compute the expectation of the transformed standard normal. The first step is to create a new version of the function Ec that allows for transformations of the random variable.

In [132]:
Ec_transformation <- function(pdf, ..., g = identity, ki = -Inf, kf = Inf){
      integrate(function(x){g(x) * pdf(x, ...)}, ki, kf)
}
In [143]:
sq <- function(x){x^2}
Ec_transformation(dchisq, df=1)
Ec_transformation(dnorm, mean=0, g=sq)

1 with absolute error < 4.9e-05
1 with absolute error < 1.2e-07
